speaker: Senator
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Enter FLAVIUS, with many bills in his hand

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: No care, no stop! so senseless of expense,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That he will neither know how to maintain it,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Nor cease his flow of riot: takes no account

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How things go from him, nor resumes no care

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Of what is to continue: never mind

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Was to be so unwise, to be so kind.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What shall be done? he will not hear, till feel:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Fie, fie, fie, fie!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Good even, Varro: what,

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: You come for money?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant Is't not your business too?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: It is: and yours too, Isidore?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Isidore's Servant It is so.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Would we were all discharged!

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant I fear it.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Here comes the lord.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, and Lords,  and c

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: So soon as dinner's done, we'll forth again,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: My Alcibiades. With me? what is your will?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Dues! Whence are you?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Of Athens here, my lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go to my steward.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Please it your lordship, he hath put me off

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: To the succession of new days this month:

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: My master is awaked by great occasion

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: To call upon his own, and humbly prays you

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: That with your other noble parts you'll suit

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: In giving him his right.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Mine honest friend,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I prithee, but repair to me next morning.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Nay, good my lord,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Contain thyself, good friend.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Varro's Servant One Varro's servant, my good lord,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Isidore's Servant From Isidore;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: He humbly prays your speedy payment.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: If you did know, my lord, my master's wants--

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant 'Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks And past.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Isidore's Servant          Your steward puts me off, my lord;

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: And I am sent expressly to your lordship.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Give me breath.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll wait upon you instantly.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt ALCIBIADES and Lords

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To FLAVIUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Come hither: pray you,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How goes the world, that I am thus encounter'd

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: With clamourous demands of date-broke bonds,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And the detention of long-since-due debts,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Against my honour?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Please you, gentlemen,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The time is unagreeable to this business:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Your importunacy cease till after dinner,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That I may make his lordship understand

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Wherefore you are not paid.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Do so, my friends. See them well entertain'd.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Pray, draw near.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Enter APEMANTUS and Fool

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Stay, stay, here comes the fool with Apemantus:

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: let's ha' some sport with 'em.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant Hang him, he'll abuse us.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Isidore's Servant A plague upon him, dog!

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant How dost, fool?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Dost dialogue with thy shadow?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Varro's Servant I speak not to thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No,'tis to thyself.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To the Fool

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Come away.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Isidore's Servant There's the fool hangs on your back already.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No, thou stand'st single, thou'rt not on him yet.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Where's the fool now?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: He last asked the question. Poor rogues, and

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: usurers' men! bawds between gold and want!

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: What are we, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Asses.

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Why?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That you ask me what you are, and do not know

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: yourselves. Speak to 'em, fool.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: How do you, gentlemen?

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Gramercies, good fool: how does your mistress?

speaker: Fool
text_entry: She's e'en setting on water to scald such chickens

speaker: Fool
text_entry: as you are. Would we could see you at Corinth!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Good! gramercy.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Enter Page

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Look you, here comes my mistress' page.

speaker: Page
text_entry: [To the Fool]  Why, how now, captain! what do you

speaker: Page
text_entry: in this wise company? How dost thou, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Would I had a rod in my mouth, that I might answer

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: thee profitably.

speaker: Page
text_entry: Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription of

speaker: Page
text_entry: these letters: I know not which is which.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Canst not read?

speaker: Page
text_entry: No.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: There will little learning die then, that day thou

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: art hanged. This is to Lord Timon; this to

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Alcibiades. Go; thou wast born a bastard, and thou't

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: die a bawd.

speaker: Page
text_entry: Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou shalt famish a

speaker: Page
text_entry: dog's death. Answer not; I am gone.

speaker: Page
text_entry: Exit

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: E'en so thou outrunnest grace. Fool, I will go with

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: you to Lord Timon's.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Will you leave me there?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: If Timon stay at home. You three serve three usurers?

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Ay; would they served us!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So would I,--as good a trick as ever hangman served thief.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Are you three usurers' men?

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Ay, fool.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant: my

speaker: Fool
text_entry: mistress is one, and I am her fool. When men come

speaker: Fool
text_entry: to borrow of your masters, they approach sadly, and

speaker: Fool
text_entry: go away merry; but they enter my mistress' house

speaker: Fool
text_entry: merrily, and go away sadly: the reason of this?

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Varro's Servant I could render one.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Do it then, that we may account thee a whoremaster

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: and a knave; which not-withstanding, thou shalt be

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: no less esteemed.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Varro's Servant What is a whoremaster, fool?

speaker: Fool
text_entry: A fool in good clothes, and something like thee.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: 'Tis a spirit: sometime't appears like a lord;

speaker: Fool
text_entry: sometime like a lawyer; sometime like a philosopher,

speaker: Fool
text_entry: with two stones moe than's artificial one: he is

speaker: Fool
text_entry: very often like a knight; and, generally, in all

speaker: Fool
text_entry: shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore

speaker: Fool
text_entry: to thirteen, this spirit walks in.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Varro's Servant Thou art not altogether a fool.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Nor thou altogether a wise man: as much foolery as

speaker: Fool
text_entry: I have, so much wit thou lackest.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That answer might have become Apemantus.

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Aside, aside; here comes Lord Timon.

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Re-enter TIMON and FLAVIUS

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Come with me, fool, come.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: I do not always follow lover, elder brother and

speaker: Fool
text_entry: woman; sometime the philosopher.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Exeunt APEMANTUS and Fool

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Pray you, walk near: I'll speak with you anon.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt Servants

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You make me marvel: wherefore ere this time

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Had you not fully laid my state before me,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That I might so have rated my expense,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As I had leave of means?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: You would not hear me,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: At many leisures I proposed.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go to:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Perchance some single vantages you took.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: When my indispos ition put you back:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And that unaptness made your minister,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thus to excuse yourself.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O my good lord,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: At many times I brought in my accounts,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Laid them before you; you would throw them off,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And say, you found them in mine honesty.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When, for some trifling present, you have bid me

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Return so much, I have shook my head and wept;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Yea, 'gainst the authority of manners, pray'd you

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To hold your hand more close: I did endure

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Not seldom, nor no slight cheques, when I have

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Prompted you in the ebb of your estate

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And your great flow of debts. My loved lord,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Though you hear now, too late--yet now's a time--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The greatest of your having lacks a half

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To pay your present debts.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Let all my land be sold.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: 'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And what remains will hardly stop the mouth

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Of present dues: the future comes apace:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What shall defend the interim? and at length

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How goes our reckoning?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O my good lord, the world is but a word:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Were it all yours to give it in a breath,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How quickly were it gone!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You tell me true.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Call me before the exactest auditors

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When all our offices have been oppress'd

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: With drunken spilth of wine, when every room

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Hath blazed with lights and bray'd with minstrelsy,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I have retired me to a wasteful cock,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And set mine eyes at flow.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Prithee, no more.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: This night englutted! Who is not Timon's?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Lord Timon's?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The breath is gone whereof this praise is made:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Feast-won, fast-lost; one cloud of winter showers,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: These flies are couch'd.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Come, sermon me no further:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: No villanous bounty yet hath pass'd my heart;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If I would broach the vessels of my love,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And try the argument of hearts by borrowing,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Men and men's fortunes could I frankly use

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As I can bid thee speak.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Assurance bless your thoughts!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And, in some sort, these wants of mine are crown'd,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That I account them blessings; for by these

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Shall I try friends: you shall perceive how you

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Mistake my fortunes; I am wealthy in my friends.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants

speaker: Servants
text_entry: My lord? my lord?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I will dispatch you severally; you to Lord Lucius;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: to Lord Lucullus you: I hunted with his honour

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: to-day: you, to Sempronius: commend me to their

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: loves, and, I am proud, say, that my occasions have

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: found time to use 'em toward a supply of money: let

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: the request be fifty talents.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: As you have said, my lord.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  Lord Lucius and Lucullus? hum!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go you, sir, to the senators--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Of whom, even to the state's best health, I have

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Deserved this hearing--bid 'em send o' the instant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A thousand talents to me.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I have been bold--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For that I knew it the most general way--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To them to use your signet and your name;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But they do shake their heads, and I am here

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: No richer in return.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Is't true? can't be?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: They answer, in a joint and corporate voice,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Do what they would; are sorry--you are honourable,--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But yet they could have wish'd--they know not--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Something hath been amiss--a noble nature

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: May catch a wrench--would all were well--'tis pity;--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And so, intending other serious matters,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: After distasteful looks and these hard fractions,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: They froze me into silence.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You gods, reward them!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Have their ingratitude in them hereditary:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Their blood is caked, 'tis cold, it seldom flows;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: 'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And nature, as it grows again toward earth,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Is fashion'd for the journey, dull and heavy.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To a Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go to Ventidius.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To FLAVIUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Prithee, be not sad,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou art true and honest; ingeniously I speak.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: No blame belongs to thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ventidius lately

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Buried his father; by whose death he's stepp'd

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Into a great estate: when he was poor,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Imprison'd and in scarcity of friends,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I clear'd him with five talents: greet him from me;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Bid him suppose some good necessity

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Touches his friend, which craves to be remember'd

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: With those five talents.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To FLAVIUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That had, give't these fellows

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To whom 'tis instant due. Ne'er speak, or think,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That Timon's fortunes 'mong his friends can sink.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I would I could not think it: that thought is

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: bounty's foe;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Being free itself, it thinks all others so.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
